title: Trump announces plan to nominate Pompeo deputy John Sullivan as ambassador to Russia
text:
Sullivan has been the No. 2 at the State Department since early on in the Trump administration, serving briefly as acting secretary last spring when the president fired Rex Tillerson.

If confirmed by the Senate, Sullivan would take over for Huntsman, who announced his resignation from the job in August after two years in Moscow.

Sullivan would then become Trump’s Russia liaison at a time when relations between Washington and Moscow have cooled considerably, as Trump’s interactions with Russian President Vladimir Putin continue to come under heavy scrutiny. The president is also battling a widening impeachment investigation over his push for a Ukraine-led investigation into the Bidens that has ensnared top officials at the State Department.

Huntsman’s tenure in Moscow has been marked by tit-for-tat sanctions and diplomatic expulsions, fallout from Russia’s interference in the 2016 elections, and warnings that the Kremlin plans to meddle again in 2020.

The U.S. has also struggled with the Kremlin's aggression in cyberspace and its intrusion into other international affairs — most notably in Venezuela and Syria — and new diplomatic forays with North Korea, as well as the deterioration of several arms control treaties, including the longstanding Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces treaty. Trump has frequently expressed his desire to ink a new nuclear treaty with Putin to head off an arms race, though the chances of the two countries negotiating and ratifying a new deal before next year’s election are slim.

In his confirmation hearing for the deputy job, Sullivan vowed to take a hard line on Russia, calling for a “robust” response to Russia’s “intrusion into our democracy.”

Sullivan was confirmed by the Senate in 2017 by a 94-6 vote, a sizable margin in the polarized age of Trump. And Sullivan has been well-regarded at State, including under Rex Tillerson, who was widely disliked, a factor Trump nodded to in August.

But Sullivan cropped up Friday in the latest testimony secured by House Democrats for their impeachment probe, which was taking place as Trump announced Sullivan’s appointment. In a deposition before three House committees, former ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch told lawmakers that she’d been removed from her post for political reasons.

According to her prepared opening statement, Yovanovitch, a career diplomat, said she spoke to Sullivan upon being abruptly recalled from Kyiv in April. Yovanovitch told lawmakers Sullivan informed her the president had lost confidence in her, and that in the face of a concerted campaign for her ouster, State had been under pressure to fire her since the year before.

“He also said that I had done nothing wrong and that this was not like other situations where he had recalled ambassadors for cause,” Yovanovitch planned to tell lawmakers. That campaign is said to have been spearheaded by Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s personal lawyer who’s sought to dig up dirt, with Ukraine’s help, on Trump’s potential 2020 rival Joe Biden.

There’s been no indication thus far that Sullivan had any involvement in Trump and Giuliani’s plans, but Democrats have lashed the State Department for stonewalling and blocking witness testimony for their investigation. Last week, Democrats sent Sullivan a letter demanding State begin cooperating with its investigation, accusing Secretary of State Mike Pompeo of having conflicts of interest with regards to the probe.
